history_facts.fact: The Great Wall of China is over 13,000 miles long.
The Roman Empire lasted for over 1,000 years.
The Egyptian pyramids were built over 4,500 years ago.
Cleopatra VII was the last active ruler of the Ptolemaic Kingdom of Egypt.
The ancient city of Pompeii was destroyed by the eruption of Mount Vesuvius in 79 AD.
The Magna Carta, signed in 1215, is considered one of the most important legal documents in history.
The Black Death, one of the deadliest pandemics in human history, killed an estimated 75-200 million people in the 14th century.
Joan of Arc, a peasant girl from France, played a key role in the Hundred Years' War and was later canonized as a saint.
The Renaissance, a period of great cultural and intellectual change, began in Italy in the 14th century.
Leonardo da Vinci painted the Mona Lisa, one of the most famous paintings in the world, during the Renaissance.
The Age of Exploration saw European explorers such as Christopher Columbus and Vasco da Gama sail to new continents and establish trade routes.
The Industrial Revolution, which began in the 18th century, transformed economies and societies by introducing mechanized production.
The French Revolution, which began in 1789, overthrew the absolute monarchy in France and led to the rise of Napoleon Bonaparte.
The Declaration of Independence, adopted in 1776, announced the thirteen American colonies' independence from British rule.
World War I, also known as the Great War, lasted from 1914 to 1918 and involved many countries from around the world.
The fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989 marked the symbolic end of the Cold War.
The internet, originally developed in the late 20th century, has revolutionized communication and information sharing worldwide.
Nelson Mandela, South Africa's first black president, was elected in 1994, ending apartheid in the country.
The first successful powered flight by the Wright brothers took place on December 17, 1903, near Kitty Hawk, North Carolina.
The assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria in 1914 triggered the start of World War I.
The signing of the Treaty of Versailles in 1919 officially ended World War I.
The sinking of the Titanic in 1912 remains one of the deadliest maritime disasters in history.
The construction of the Panama Canal, completed in 1914, revolutionized global maritime trade.
The founding of the United Nations in 1945 aimed to promote international cooperation and prevent future conflicts.
The Apollo 11 mission, launched in 1969, successfully landed the first humans on the moon.
The end of apartheid in South Africa led to the election of Nelson Mandela as president in 1994.
The 1969 Woodstock Music Festival became a symbol of the counterculture movement of the 1960s.
The Chernobyl nuclear disaster in 1986 remains one of the worst nuclear accidents in history.
The fall of the Soviet Union in 1991 marked the end of the Cold War era.
The invention of the printing press by Johannes Gutenberg in the 15th century revolutionized the spread of knowledge.
The American Civil War, fought from 1861 to 1865, resulted in the abolition of slavery in the United States.
The French Revolution, which began in 1789, led to the rise of Napoleon Bonaparte and the spread of revolutionary ideals across Europe.
The Berlin Wall, built in 1961, divided East and West Berlin until its fall in 1989.
The assassination of President John F. Kennedy in 1963 shocked the world and sparked numerous conspiracy theories.
The Renaissance, a period of cultural and artistic rebirth, saw the emergence of great thinkers such as Leonardo da Vinci and Michelangelo.
The Spanish Inquisition, established in 1478, aimed to root out heresy in Spain and its territories.
The Enlightenment, an intellectual movement of the 17th and 18th centuries, emphasized reason, science, and individualism.
The Battle of Waterloo in 1815 marked the final defeat of Napoleon Bonaparte and the end of the Napoleonic Wars.
The sinking of the RMS Lusitania in 1915, by a German U-boat, played a role in bringing the United States into World War I.
The construction of the Suez Canal in the 19th century revolutionized global trade and transportation.
The assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria in 1914 triggered the outbreak of World War I.
The Industrial Revolution, which began in Britain in the late 18th century, transformed society with innovations such as the steam engine.
The Bolshevik Revolution in 1917 led to the establishment of the Soviet Union and the spread of communism.
The signing of the Treaty of Versailles in 1919 officially ended World War I.
The Battle of Stalingrad in 1942-1943 was one of the largest and deadliest battles of World War II.
The dropping of atomic bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki in 1945 led to the end of World War II.
The Russian Revolution of 1917 led to the overthrow of the Tsarist autocracy and the rise of the Soviet Union.
The signing of the Treaty of Versailles in 1919 officially ended World War I.
The Spanish flu pandemic of 1918-1919 infected an estimated 500 million people worldwide and killed millions.
The sinking of the RMS Titanic in 1912 remains one of the deadliest maritime disasters in history.
The signing of the Magna Carta in 1215 established the principle of the rule of law and limited the power of the monarchy.
The Great Fire of London in 1666 destroyed much of the city, leading to significant rebuilding efforts.
The Trail of Tears, a forced relocation of Native American tribes, resulted in thousands of deaths in the 1830s.
The Holocaust, the systematic genocide of six million Jews by the Nazis during World War II, remains one of the darkest chapters in human history.
The construction of the Panama Canal, completed in 1914, revolutionized global maritime trade.
The signing of the Treaty of Versailles in 1919 officially ended World War I.
